items.content: Paramedics treated three military personnel at scene of single-vehicle incident near Townsville on Wednesday nightFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastAn Australian army soldier has died and two others have been injured in an accident during training in north Queensland.The soldier was fatally injured in a vehicle rollover during a training course at the Townsville Field Training Area near Townsville on Wednesday, a Defence spokesperson said. items.title: Soldier dies, two others injured after 'training incident' in Queensland
items.standfirst: P aramedics were called to the scene outside Townsville yesterday evening.
items.content: A soldier has died after a crash at a Townsville military base in northern Queensland.Defence Minister and Deputy Prime Minister Richard Marles has confirmed that the soldier had died after a "training incident" about 6.42pm yesterday.Queensland Ambulance Service confirmed they were called to the scene of a sin gle-vehicle crash on Hervey Range Road.READ MORE: Aussie city set to shatter blistering 37-year heat recordhttps://x.com/RichardMarlesMP/status/1978626812394836188Multiple paramedic units, including a rescue helicopter, attended.One person suffered life-threatening injuries, and has since died."This is a tragic loss and the sacrifice of our service personnel weighs heavily on us all," Marles said."Our service men and women wear our nation's uniform with pride and we recognise the risks they take each and every day in the defence of our nation."Two other soldiers, including a man in his 30s and a man in his 20s, were taken to hospital in a stable condition.It's understood they have since been discharged. READ MORE: Israel, Hamas swap bodies after 'hostage' error threatens peaceThe Department of Defence confirmed in a statement there had been an "incident involving Australian Defence Force personnel" near Townsville last night."The welfare of ADF members and their families is a priority and Defence's focus is on supporting those involved," a spokesperson said."Due to the developing nature of the incident, no further information will be available at this time and we request the privacy of Defence members and families is respected."The spokesperson said further updates would be provided as they became available. DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.standfirst: Home affairs minister’s 2024 decision to reject visa application for planned speaking tour on character grounds upheldFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastAustralia’s high court has unanimously backed the government’s 2024 decision to refuse the rightwing provocateur Candace Owens a visa to enter the country.The full bench of the court ruled on Wednesday that the minister’s denial did not infringe an implied constitutional freedom of political communication. Continue reading...

items.title: AFP promises ‘swift action’ after Albanese, Ley and Morrison’s private phone numbers exposed online
items.standfirst: Richard Marles says investigation under way into how the prime minister and other senior government staff’s phone numbers appeared in databasesFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastFederal police are scrambling to assist politicians after the private phone numbers of Anthony Albanese, Sussan Ley, Scott Morrison and senior government staff were discovered to be freely available in large contact databases published by American marketing companies.The Australian federal police is seeking to have prime minister Albanese’s number removed from such databases, where it is available to users free of charge, and to assist other federal parliamentarians who have been similarly exposed. Police have warned that harassment by phone or carriage service is illegal, and promised “swift action” against those breaching such laws. Continue reading...
items.content: Richard Marles says investigation under way into how the prime minister and other senior government staff’s phone numbers appeared in databasesFollow our Australia news live blog for latest updatesGet our breaking news email, free app or daily news podcastFederal police are scrambling to assist politicians after the private phone numbers of Anthony Albanese, Sussan Ley, Scott Morrison and senior government staff were discovered to be freely available in large contact databases published by American marketing companies.The Australian federal police is seeking to have prime minister Albanese’s number removed from such databases, where it is available to users free of charge, and to assist other federal parliamentarians who have been similarly exposed. Police have warned that harassment by phone or carriage service is illegal, and promised “swift action” against those breaching such laws. Continue reading...

clusters.title: Remains found in search for missing Victorian woman
clusters.neutral_headline: Human Remains Found in Search for Missing Victorian Woman

items.title: Remains found in search for missing Victorian woman
items.standfirst: Miller, 24, went missing on October 16, 2022 after taking a rideshare car home from Melbourne to Neerim South in West Gippsland, regional Victoria, about 11.30am.
items.content: H uman remains have been found in the search for missing Victorian woman Lucinda Miller.Miller, 24, was last seen on October 16, 2022 after she took a rideshare car home from Melbourne to Neerim South in West Gippsland, regional Victoria, about 11.30am.Police launched a fresh search for Miller this week three years after her disappearance.READ MORE: Trump secured peace deal through 'force', says former ambassador to Israel READ MORE: Aussie city set to shatter blistering 37-year heat recordThe remains were located this morning on the anniversary of her disappearance, police have confirmed.Her death is not being treated as suspicious.Around 60 people were involved in the renewed search effort this week."Local police would like to extend their thanks to the Neerim South CFA, SES, DEECA and the AFP for their support and assistance," police said in a statement.Authorities began scouring bushland arond two kilometres north of the original search area around McDougal Road in Neerim South on Monday.Police used dogs capable of sniffing out electronic devices in the hope of finding Miller's phone. READ MORE: More than a million households at critical stress point Detectives appealed to anyone who had been walking in bushland around McDougal Road, near the intersection of Whitelaw Track, to come forward.Detective Senior Constable Michael Fowler said earlier that search crews would be keeping an eye out for Miller's clothes and two vodka bottles she was known to be carrying.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Remains of missing Gippsland woman found after three years
items.standfirst: Police have uncovered human remains in bushland in Victoria's east believed to be missing woman Lucinda Miller.
items.content: Police have uncovered human remains in bushland in Victoria's east believed to be missing woman Lucinda Miller.

ai_summary: Police discovered human remains in Victorian bushland.
The remains are believed to be those of Lucinda Miller.

She was last seen taking a rideshare from Melbourne.
The rideshare was to Neerim South in West Gippsland.
